conclusion: Analyze the motion of the particle in both the magnetic field and the electric field.
The particle starts at the origin O with an initial velocity vi at a 45° angle to the y-axis.
Initial velocity components are v_ix = v_i / sqrt(2) and v_iy = v_i / sqrt(2).
In the magnetic field, the particle will undergo circular motion because the magnetic force is always perpendicular to the velocity.
The radius R of the circular path is R = mv_i / qB.
After one complete revolution, the particle returns to the same x-coordinate but with the opposite y-component of velocity.
The particle eventually ends up at point P(3L, L) in the electric field.
Assume the particle exits the magnetic field at point Q(x_1, -y_1).
The y-component of the velocity will be zero at the exit point because the particle is moving horizontally when it enters the electric field.
The particle completes a semicircle in the magnetic field.
The time taken to complete a semicircle is t_m = πm / qB.
Once the particle enters the electric field, it experiences a constant acceleration in the negative y-direction due to the electric field.
Equations of motion in the electric field are x = x_1 + v_ix t_e and y = -y_1 - (1/2)(qE/m)t_e^2.
The particle reaches point P(3L, L) with a velocity V_0 along the positive x-axis.
From the velocity component, v_i = V_0 sqrt(2).
Substituting v_i into the x-coordinate equation gives 3L = x_1 + V_0 t_e.
Substituting v_i into the y-coordinate equation gives L = -y_1 - (1/2)(qE/m)t_e^2.
The radius R is R = mV_0 sqrt(2) / qB.
